demo.name: nation
demo.value: National

demo.name: para#1
demo.value: By 2030, the number of jobs in the United States is expected to reach 165.4 million, a net increase of more than 2.6 million jobs from 2019, before the pandemic. While 9.3 million jobs were lost during the pandemic, the recovery has been relatively robust and fast. In addition to positions added in the pandemic recovery, the U.S. economy is expected to gain an additional 2.6 million jobs, including 1.4 million healthcare support jobs, by 2030.

demo.name: para#2
demo.value:
While this is positive news, the challenge will be to fill these jobs. Of the 165.4 million jobs expected to exist in 2030, almost half, or 80.1 million, will be vacated by people retiring, changing careers, or leaving the labor market altogether. These 80.1 million jobs do not include workers who change positions within the same occupation.

U.S.-born workers are more likely than foreign-born workers to reach retirement age. In total, 23.6 percent of U.S.-born workers, or 31 million, will reach retirement age by 2030. Immigrant workers, on the other hand, are less likely to reach retirement age, with 21.9 percent, or 6.0 million, reaching age 65 by 2030.

Younger workers are more likely to be foreign-born. In 2019, 21.6 million of 121.4 million workers under age 55 were foreign born, a share of 17.8 percent. In comparison, 27.7 million workers out of all 160.2 million workers in the U.S. were foreign born, a share of 17.3 percent.

While many jobs will be filled by people aging into the workforce, demographic trends suggest that the labor market in 2030 will still need more immigrant workers. As a smaller generation than previous ones, Gen Z—comprised of those born after 1996—is likely to produce fewer U.S.-born workers than the baby boomers, who are leaving the workforce. The gap between this growing demand and diminishing supply of U.S.-born workers means that more workers will need to come from abroad or these positions will go unfilled.

demo.name: management
demo.value: Management

demo.name: para#1
demo.value: By 2030, the number of U.S. jobs in management occupations is expected to be 10.7 million, close to the number of jobs before the 2020 pandemic. While many jobs (915,000) were lost during the pandemic, the recovery is expected to be robust and relatively fast. It includes management jobs in healthcare, food service, and marketing.

demo.name: para#2
demo.value:
While this is positive news, the challenge will be filling these jobs. Of the 10.7 million management jobs expected to exist in 2030, about 25 percent, or 2.7 million, will be vacated by people retiring or leaving the labor market.

U.S.-born workers in management occupations are more likely to reach retirement age. By 2030, more than 4 million U.S.-born workers will reach retirement age. Immigrant workers, on the other hand, are less likely to reach retirement age: 28.1 percent of U.S.-born workers were over the age of 55 in 2019, compared with just 22.1 percent of immigrant workers.

While new workers aging into the workforce will fill millions of open jobs by 2030, demographic trends suggest that the workforce in 2030 will rely on more immigrant workers, either who are already here or who will need to come from abroad. Of the current workforce, 15.2 percent of those who are not expected to retire or exit the labor force by 2030 are foreign-born, a percentage that’s higher than the foreign-born share of all workers in 2019, meaning workers who will stay in the labor force in the next decade are more likely to be immigrants. Because Gen Z is likely to produce fewer people aging into the workforce than will be leaving it, more workers will need to come from abroad to fill the growing shortage of American workers. Otherwise, these positions will go unfilled.

demo.name: engineering
demo.value: Architecture & Engineering

demo.name: para#1
demo.value: By 2030, the number of jobs in architecture and engineering occupations, including electrical engineer, civil engineer, and engineering technician, is expected to reach 2.7 million, a net increase of 19,900 jobs from early 2020, before the pandemic. While many jobs (126,000) were lost during the early stages of the pandemic, the recovery is expected to be robust and relatively fast.

demo.name: para#2
demo.value:
While this is positive news, the challenge will be filling these jobs. Of the 2.7 million architecture and engineering jobs expected to exist in 2030, 23.5 percent, or 640,000, will be vacated by people retiring or leaving the labor market. These vacated jobs do not include workers who change jobs within the same occupation.

U.S.-born workers are more likely to reach retirement age. By 2030, 673,600 U.S.-born workers in these fields will reach retirement age. Immigrant workers, on the other hand, are less likely to reach retirement age. About 25.3 percent of U.S.-born workers were over the age of 55 in 2019, compared with just 22.8 percent of immigrant workers.

Younger workers who won’t reach retirement age are more likely to be foreign-born.In 2019, about 20.1 percent of these workers under age 55 were foreign-born, compared to 19.6 percent of the overall workforce, making these sectors more reliant on immigrant workers in the next decade.

While many jobs will be filled by young people aging into the workforce, demographic trends suggest that the workforce in 2030 will need more immigrant workers. Because Gen Z is likely to produce fewer people aging into the workforce than will be leaving it, more workers will need to come from abroad to fill the growing shortage of American workers. Otherwise these positions will go unfilled.

demo.name: para#1
demo.value: By 2030, the number of U.S. jobs in the life, physical, & social sciences is expected to reach 1.6 million, an increase of 96,800 jobs from early 2020, before the pandemic. On top of this, the U.S. economy is expected to gain an additional 97,500 new jobs in these sciences, including jobs in clinical counseling and those as science technicians, chemists, and biologists.

demo.name: para#2
demo.value:
While this is positive news, the challenge will be filling these jobs. Of the 1.6 million life sciences jobs expected to exist in in 2030, about 20 percent, or 310,000, will be vacated by people retiring or leaving the labor market.

U.S.-born workers in the sciences are more likely to reach retirement age. By 2030, more than 299,000 U.S.-born workers will reach retirement age. Immigrant workers, on the other hand, are less likely to reach retirement age: 22.6 percent of U.S.-born workers were over the age of 55 in 2019, compared with just 17.8 percent of immigrant workers.

While new workers aging into the workforce will fill millions of these open jobs by 2030, demographic trends suggest that the workforce in 2030 will rely on more immigrant workers—either who are already here or who will need to come from abroad. Of current workers not expected to retire or exit the labor force by 2030, 22 percent are foreign-born, higher than the foreign-born share of all workers in these fields 2019. Because Gen Z is likely to produce fewer people aging into the workforce than will be leaving it, more workers will need to come from abroad to fill the growing shortage of American workers. Otherwise these positions will go unfilled.

demo.name: para#1
demo.value: By 2030, the number of U.S. jobs in farming, fishing, and forestry is expected to remain stable at 1.1 million. While many jobs (54,200) were lost during the pandemic, about half of those jobs (26,600) are expected to come back in the next couple of years, including those as farm laborer, rancher, and grader and sorter of agricultural products.

demo.name: para#2
demo.value:
While this is positive news, the challenge will be filling these jobs. Of the 1.1 million farming, fishing, and forestry jobs expected to exist in 2030, about 40.5 percent, or 452,000, will be vacated by people retiring or leaving the labor market.

U.S.-born workers are more likely to reach retirement age. By 2030, more than 126,000 U.S.-born workers in these fields will reach retirement age. Immigrant workers, on the other hand, are less likely to reach retirement age. About 23.9 percent of U.S.-born workers were over the age of 55 in 2019, compared with just 20.4 percent of immigrant workers.

Younger workers who won’t reach retirement age are more likely to be foreign-born. In 2019, about 46.3 percent of the workforce under the age of 55 was foreign-born, compared with 44.2 percent of the overall workforce.

While many jobs will be filled by young people aging into the workforce, demographic trends suggest that the workforce in 2030 will need more immigrant workers. Because Gen Z is likely to produce fewer people aging into the workforce than will be leaving it, more workers will need to come from abroad to fill the growing shortage of American workers. Otherwise these positions will go unfilled.

demo.name: production
demo.value: Production

demo.name: para#1
demo.value: By 2030, the number of U.S. jobs in production are expected to decrease to 8.7 million. Many office jobs (680,000) were lost during the pandemic, including those as inspector, tester, team assembler, and others.

demo.name: para#2
demo.value:
While there will be a loss of production jobs, there remains the challenge of filling jobs left by people leaving the workforce. Of the 8.7 million production jobs expected to exist in 2030, about 34.9 percent, or 3.3 million, will be vacated by people retiring or leaving the labor market.

U.S.-born workers are more likely to reach retirement age. By 2030, more than 1.6 million U.S.-born workers will reach retirement age. Immigrant workers, on the other hand, are less likely to reach retirement age: about 26.8 percent of U.S.-born workers in the field were over the age of 55 in 2019, compared with just 22.6 percent of immigrant workers.

Many production workers will reach retirement age. Over one-fifth of these workers in the United States, regardless of immigration status, were over the age of 55 in 2019. By 2030, more than 1.6 million U.S.-born workers and 512,000 immigrant workers will reach retirement age.

While many jobs will be filled by young people aging into the workforce, demographic trends suggest that the workforce in 2030 will need more immigrant workers. Because Gen Z is likely to produce fewer people aging into the workforce than will be leaving it, more workers will need to come from abroad to fill the growing shortage of American workers. Otherwise these positions will go unfilled.

demo.name: production
demo.value: Community & Social Service

demo.name: para#1
demo.value: By 2030, the number of jobs in community and social service occupations, such as mental health counselor, social worker, and health educator, is expected to reach 3.2 million, a net increase of 347,000 jobs from early 2020, before the pandemic.

demo.name: para#2
demo.value:
While this is positive news, the challenge will be filling these jobs. Of the 3.2 million jobs expected to exist in these fields in 2030, over one-third, or 1 million, will be vacated by people retiring or leaving the labor market. These vacated jobs do not include workers who change jobs within the same occupation.

Many community and social service workers will reach retirement age. At least one-fourth of these workers in the United States, regardless of immigration status, were over the age of 55 in 2019. By 2030, more than 655,000 U.S.-born workers and 81,000 immigrant workers will reach retirement age.

While many jobs will be filled by young people aging into the workforce, demographic trends suggest that the workforce in 2030 will need more immigrant workers. Because Gen Z is likely to produce fewer people aging into the workforce than will be leaving it, more workers will need to come from abroad to fill the growing shortage of American workers. Otherwise these positions will go unfilled.
